module.name: fpg_main
module.short: The main unit that ties everything together from CoreLib

descr.p: . This unit contain the higher level classes that the end-user will use to build applications.
This unit also contains the global objects instances used to start an application, or helper functions used through a a fpGUI based application. eg: , .

element.name: fpgPostMessage
element.short: Posts a message to the event queue
element.descr: fpgPostMessage posts a message to the event queue, but doesn't wait for it to compelete. It returns immediately.

element.name: fpgSendMessage
element.short: Sends a message to the event queue
element.descr: fpgSendMessage sends a message to the event queue and waits for it to complete before it returns.

element.name: fpgColorToRGB
element.short: Convert a color to RGB values of that color
element.descr: . Not all TfpgColor values are in RGB format. For example you are "named" colors too. eg: clWindowBackground

element.name: fpgGetNamedColor
element.short: Returns a "named" TfpgColor based on a RGB color

element.name: fpgSetNamedFont
element.descr: . Because fpGUI is a cross-platform toolkit, the same fonts might not be available on all systems. For this reason fpGUI supports "named" or "alias names" for fonts. You can specify a font description, and then give that font description a name. Then any component that has a FontDesc property you can pass the full font description, or the "named" font name. An example of a named font is '#Edit1' which is the default font used for TfpgEdit.
